newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: LITHUANIA-LITEKSAS & CALW NOT TO PAY DIVIDENDS.
newsitem.headline: LITHUANIA-LITEKSAS & CALW NOT TO PAY DIVIDENDS.

text.p: Lithuania's wool fabric producer Liteksas & Calw said on Wednesday it will keep its 1996 profit within the company and will not pay dividends.
"The general shareholders meeting decided on Tuesday to keep the net profit in the company's reserves," director general of the company, Virgilijus Varzha, told Reuters.
Varzha also said the shareholders meeting approved the company's 1996 profit of 2.3 million litas. Liteksas & Calw had around three million litas losses the year before, he said.
The share capital of the company is 47.8 million litas.
"The shareholders decided not to boost the share capital so far," Varzha said.
But he did not exclude the possibility that a share capital boost may take place this year.
The company is 68 percent owned by German Calwer Decken.
International Finance Corporation, part of the World Bank, and Germany's Development Fund DEG own eight percent each of the company. The rest of the shares are owned by local investors, Varzha said.

Varzha also said the company plans to produce and sell three million metres of woollen fabrics in 1997 versus 2.3 million metres last year although he declined to say how much this output would worth.
Liteks and Calw is listed on group A of Vilnius bourse.
